oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Baptist Church, Kingston: front view
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 4600 Ninth Ave. N, Birmingham, Jefferson County, AL

Color photograph of the front of the brick church, viewed from ground level. The church has a full basement, which raises the sanctuary level. The entrance,to the sanctuary is a paneled double door entry under a blind round arched over panel over which a projecting portico with pediment, supported by wrought iron posts and with a wrought iron railing. Flanking the central entrance are metal framed four pane rectangular slag glass windows painted blue. The sanctuary level is reached by flight of concrete and brick staircases to the left. An entrance to the basement level is just below the primary entrance, leading under the portico. A sign above the sanctuary doors reads "The Lighthouse Church Ministries," reflecting the church ownership at the time of nomination. An awning over the basement entry reads "F B K," representing the original church name. A banner reads: "Lighthouse Church Ministries. Pastor and founder: Roderice James Holt, Sr. We are the light in the world."

First Baptist Church, Kingston was one of the leading Birmingham churches involved in the Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights during the Civil Rights era of the 1950s and 1960s. Reverend George W. Dickerson, an officer in the ACMHR and active leader in the organization until his death, led the congregation from 1941 to 1972. The church was one of the early activist congregations in the ACMHR. It also held one of the most significant ACMHR mass meetings on May 15, 1961, the night following the vicious mob attack on the Freedom Riders at the Trailways Station in downtown Birmingham. The church was the location of five ACMHR mass meetings recorded in 1961 and 1962.
